did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Historical Collections, Claude Moore Health Sciences Library, University of Virginia
did.unittitle: The Papers of the Albemarle County Medical Society 1933-2002

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Papers of the Albemarle County Medical Society, Accession #MS-29, Historical Collections, Claude Moore Health Sciences Library, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by the Albemarle County Medical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: The Seal of the Albemarle County Medical Society (ACMS) indicates that it was organized in 1914, but Dr. Armistead Page Booker who wrote an unfinished draft of the history of the society postulated that it may have existed as early as 1851. He quotes Dr. Wyndham Blanton in "Medicine in Virginia in the Nineteenth Century" as noting, "in January 1851, the 'Stethoscope,' a medical journal of that time, reported that there was a local society in Charlottesville." Booker's draft continues to trace the early days and states, "in the first published list of the component [local] societies, in the 22 January 1915 issue of the 'Virginia Medical Semi-Monthly,' there is the 'Doctors' Club' with Dr. J. Carroll Flippin as President and Dr. Halstead S. Hedges as Secretary. In October 1915, in the 'Transactions,' there is a listing of the component state societies, by congressional districts, as well as the names and places of residence of all of the members. The only local society included, the 'Albemarle County Society,' had 38 members." By 1925 membership had grown to 79 active members. In 1950 there were 131 and by 1982 the number reached 475. Booker points out that many members distinguished themselves over the years as teachers, practitioners, original thinkers in clinical and basic research, and leaders in organized medicine.

The Society has served as an arena for scientific talks and socializing as well as a forum for legislative information and action and community service. The Society was the driving force behind the mass oral polio virus vaccinations that were given in the Charlottesville area in the early 1960s. The Society weighed in on fluoridation of the Charlottesville water supply, health care of the elderly, medical malpractice, driving under the influence, and seat belts, and has lobbied state and national representatives concerning medically related legislation. That lobbying has resulted in letters from Lyndon B. Johnson, John F. Kennedy, Harry F. Byrd, Thomas J. Michie, Virginius Dabney, and Huburt H. Humphrey among others.

The "Albemarle Medical News" has been published by the ACMS since Spring 1992. Originally a quarterly, it is now published twice a year. It includes medical articles of interest, legislative updates, memoriams for members, and medical students news. Its inaugural issue states that there are nearly 500 physicians (almost evenly divided between University physicians and physicians in private practice) who are members of the ACMS and that it is a component of the Medical Society of Virginia. The "Message from the President" goes on to say, "Our business is communication. Our monthly meeting is almost like the old town meeting where everyone gets brought up to date on the latest developments in medicine and then gets a chance to give feedback. We discuss local medical problems and help find solutions to them. At each meeting we have a scientific presentation of broad clinical interest. After the business and the scientific portions of the meeting we have a reception and dinner together."

Over the years the Society has financially supported varous entities including the American Medical Education Fund, the Medical Student Scholarship Fund, the local rescue squads, the Bessie Dunn Miller Cancer Center, and the Virginia Council on Health and Medical Care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection includes five boxes of membership applications; four boxes of subject-related files, including committee papers, the government and bylaws of ACMS, resolutions passed, and the women's auxiliary; one box of minutes from years 1951 to 2001; one box of correspondence from 1948-2002; and three boxes of financial records beginning in 1933. There is one photograph of nineteen of the presidents of the ACMS taken in 1981.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Boxes 1-5 are arranged alphabetically by the last names of the membership applicants, boxes 6-9 are arranged alphabetically by subject, and boxes 10-14 are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Included topics are sewage disposal, well baby clinic in Crozet, visiting nurses, need for a Health Center for Charlottesville and Albemarle, Milk Ordinance, and fluoridation.
Includes letters regarding the Jenkins-Keough Bill signed by U.S. Representative Howard K. Smith, U.S. Senator A. Willis Robertson, and U.S. Senator Harry F. Byrd.

Martha Jefferson Hospital Education Liaison Fund 1979-84

scopecontent.p: This first known formal photograph of the ACMS presidents includes: Left to right, first row - Frank E. Taylor, 1980; Charles E. Hess, 1981; William B. Pollard, 1969; R. Gregory Magruder, 1949; G. Slaughter Fitz-Hugh, 1960; George R. Minor, 1967; W. Copley McLean, 1964; Wilmer H. Paine, 1936; White McK. Wallenborn, 1978; Harvey D. Smallwood, 1974. Left to right, second row - George D. Spence, 1976; Oscar A. Thorup, Jr., 1977; Edward P. Cawley, 1962; John L. Guerrant, 1965; Daniel N. Mohler, 1979; Armistead P. Booker, 1968; Harry L. Archer, 1955; Cary N. Moon, Jr., 1963; Morton C. Wilhelm, 1971.

Includes resolutions about the Wagner Act, quarantine, firing of Dr. James Druff of Western State Hospital, mental illness, prescription drugs, compensation of physicians in teaching hospitals, trash, medical care for jail prisoners, ear-piercing, Emergency Medicine Services, health care insurance, and boxing.

did.unittitle: Resolution regarding establishment of regional medical programs 1965

scopecontent.p: This resolution refers to H.R. bill Number 3140 also known as the Heart Disease, Cancer, and Stroke Amendments of 1965. Included are letters signed by U.S. Senator Harry F. Byrd, U.S. Senator A. Willis Robertson, and U.S. Representative Howard W. Smith.

did.unittitle: Resolution regarding optometrists and eye care 1977-81

scopecontent.p: Includes resolutions and correspondence about seat belts, alcohol use, child safety seats, and physical standards for the licensure of drivers. Includes letters signed by Virginia House of Delegates C. Armonde Paxson and Richard H. Middleton, and Virginia Senator Edward O. McCue.

ACMS opposes the Forand Bill which would provide certain health care services to social security recipients. Includes letters signed by Thomas J. Michie and Virginius Dabney; U.S. Representative Howard W. Smith; and U.S. Senators A. Willis Robertson, Harry F. Byrd, Lyndon B. Johnson, Huburt H. Humphrey, and John F. Kennedy.
